data.title: Toy Block
data.statement:
Your little brother is playing with toy blocks, conveniently all cubes.

He decides to build a [[x]] unit long wall with his blocks, such that the wall is a straight line. His style of building can be represented with [[N]] queries that would allow him to place one block at every unit between [[A]] and [[B]], representing the ranges at which the blocks are placed on the wall, inclusive.

When queries overlap, it means that the blocks are placed over each other. Also, to make it easier for you, the ranges are zero-indexed. 

Your task is to find the lowest and highest heights on the wall; not their location, but the height, measured in blocks.
data.stubGenerator:
read N:int x:int
loop N read A:int B:int
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> [[N]], the number of queries, and [[x]], the length of the wall.
<<Next [[N]] lines:>> [[A]] and [[B]], inclusive ranges of blocks.
data.outputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Lowest point on the wall.
<<Line 2:>> Highest point on the wall.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Your little brother is playing with toy blocks, conveniently all cubes.

He decides to build a x unit long wall with his blocks, such that the wall is a straight line. His style of building can be represented with N queries that would allow him to place one block at every unit between A and B, representing the ranges at which the blocks are placed on the wall, inclusive.

When queries overlap, it means that the blocks are placed over each other. Also, to make it easier for you, the ranges are zero-indexed.

Your task is to find the lowest and highest heights on the wall; not their location, but the height, measured in blocks.
Input
Line 1: N, the number of queries, and x, the length of the wall.
Next N lines: A and B, inclusive ranges of blocks.
Output
Line 1: Lowest point on the wall.
Line 2: Highest point on the wall.
Constraints
0 ≤ N ≤ 1000
0 < x ≤ 10000
0 ≤ A ≤ B < 10000
Example
Input
3 10
0 4
2 6
6 9
Output
1
2
